content.description: A west facing wall, tucked behind the S. Pole, that is easily overlooked.  A good tricky crux sequence that calls for some combination of balance, crimping power, and core tension.
content.protection: Anchor on gear in the horizontals above Looper.
content.location: Squeeze past the large tree that leans against the pillar and climb up the center of the face past a short, 4 inch deep right-facing corner. This face is left of (around the corner from) the Dead Battery route. The big blocks to the left and the arete to the right are off.

content.description: Some people find this route awkward, due to the mandatory wide stemming through the crux; I rather enjoy it.  This route has a tendency to be damp, but in general is climbable all season.
content.protection: Adequate.  Gear/natural anchor at the top.
content.location: In the corner where the left and right walls meet, there is a blocky dihedral; climb straight up the dihedral.  Easy walk-off.

content.description:
Pencil and Johnny were lovers... and oh, Lordie, how they could love... 

  Oops - sorry, wrong site.  And song, for that matter.  *ahem*
content.protection: Spicy to lead; must traverse right half-way up to place gear, or risk a potential ground fall.  Bolted anchor at the top - use directional to run this route on TR.
content.location: Climb the arete across the chimney mouth from Commencement (the left-most arete of the tall, vertical face on the right wall that's on the gigantic detached block).  Easy walk-off.

content.description: One of the best routes in Peterskill; good, aesthetic moves over clean rock.
content.protection: G-PG gear; small for the most part.  Bolted anchor on top.
content.location: Climb the middle of the tall, vertical face to the right of Pencel & Johnny's Arete.  Very easy to get over onto Floops (just to the left).  Easy walk-off.

content.description:
Do you cram yourself in the offwidth, or stem?  Are there snakes in the horizontals? 

  Fun route with a well-defined crux; no large gear is needed, contrary to first look.  Make sure your belayer is attentive, as you could hit the ledge.
content.protection: Good pro; nothing big is needed.  The crux protects fairly well.  Gear-only anchor.
content.location: Climb right-facing dihedral at the far end of the left wall of the Oops Wall area.  Easy walk-off.

content.description: Another excellent route, one of the best in Peterskill.
content.protection: Spicier than it's brother; small gear predominates.  Bolted anchor at the top.
content.location: Climb face between Oops and the arete to the left; beginning is generally damp, and can cause problems.  Easy walk-off.

content.description: Including this for completeness sake; never climbed it, as there is no good way to build an anchor at the top.  The only trees available are Pitch Pines (off limits), and the only gear available is under a not-too-large block.
content.protection: Unknown.  Very difficult gear anchor at the top; bring VERY long runners/static line (100+ feet) to reach allowable trees.
content.location: On the face between Stacked and the chimney; start below blocky, right-facing flake; follow flake up to a seam, seam to a small roof, traverse right to the end.  Follow face up to top.

content.description: A really nice line up a good piece of stone.  OK a spot of crumbly rock and lichen up high, but the hard work is done at that point.  The overhang at the bottom allows for some harder starts: jump to the first horizontal (dead battery = jump start...get it?), or finger traverse it in from the left.  But these feel contrived and don't really add quality to an otherwise continuous, semi-pumpy, well-protected lead.
content.protection: Normal rack to 2 or 3", but mostly it's cams up to 1" in the horizontals.  Gear anchor on the ledge at the top.
content.location: Start on the blocks 10' L of Looper and step L onto the face at a 1" deep, right angling corner.  Once you're established on the face, it's straight up.
Climb the arete 5 feet left of the Looper dihedral.  Easy walk-off to the right.

content.description:
Why is it called "Santa's Escape"?  Because it's a CHIMNEY! 

  You can get some absolutely fantastic pictures from inside the chimney, looking out; walk around the detached block, keeping it on your left - this will bring you over to the Cuckoo's Nest/Psycho Wall areas, and the other entrance to the chimney.  Walk to the end of it, and you can see/take pictures of the climber on Santa's Escape.
content.protection: There is no protection whatsoever on this route; if you fall, and your body doesn't jam to stop you, you're gonna fall a long way.  TR is the best option.  All gear anchor, using long static line to reach the cracks on top.  Use a rope bag to protect the anchor legs.
content.location: Walk into chimney approx 15 feet, just past the first large boulder.  Climb straight up to top.  Both sides of the chimney are on.  Easy walk-off.

content.description: Including for completeness sake; never climbed it, as there is no good way to build an anchor at the top.  The only trees available are Pitch Pines (off limits) and the only gear available is under a not-so-large block.
content.protection: Unknown.  Very difficult gear anchor at the top.  Bring VERY long runners/static line to reach back to allowable trees (100+ feet).
content.location: Climb the arete to the left of Stacked and Exuberance, at the mouth of the obvious chimney.  Easy walk-off.

content.description: A beautiful, clean section of rock; possibly the tallest area in Peterskill with routes in the 70-80 foot range.  Home to one of the deceptively easiest climbs, as well as two of the hardest and most popular AND the only pure chimney route in Peterskill.  Reasonably well-shaded belay areas.
